reviewText:
This game is from my childhood, and I loved it back then, and I still do. However with latest hardware, and operating systems, it has rendered this epic game completely unplayable (laggy mouse, low resolution, and crash to desktop every 5 minutes). This should have been re-worked, and re-patched, before being allowed on to Steam.

As mentioned on even the positive reviews, Desperados does not work on Windows 7/8/10. At least, not very well. I have reported this to the developers, but my thread(s) were completely ignored, and we have never received any acknowledgement that these compatibility issues even exist, even though they clearly DO. My current issue is a complete freeze up of the game after 5 minutes, followed either by a crash to desktop, or a BSOD.

It's a BRILLIANT game, but you will likely be put off of it by the performance issues before you have a chance to appreciate it's brilliance. Save your money, and just pray that the developers fix the issues with W7 and W8.

Update 1st Dec 2013: There is a directdraw" fix available in the forums which fixes mouse lag
date: however the crashing is still ongoing. It seems that patching has stopped for this game already.\n\nUpdate 25th Feb 2014: There appears to be an unofficial work around for the crashing issues available in a stickied forum thread. This is not developer supplied
recommended: and edging on the side of caution
hoursPlayed: I would prefer NOT to download random ".dll" files off of the internet - especially those hosted on rapidshare. I am unlikely to ever try the fix for myself
voteText: and the "Negative" review stands
helpfulPercent: as long as the developers fail to patch these aweful compatibility problems."
commentsCount: 221 of 278 people (79%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is not a game. This is THE game.
I've played at least 100 hours at this game when I was younger, and I'm happy to know it's on Steam now. This is on my personal top 3 of the best games I ever played. Good story, good gameplay with a mix of action and stealth, good atmosphere, good locations and the characters have a nice voice acting (In Italian).

Anyway, if you have Windows 7/8, I suggest to DON'T BUY this game, because it doesn't run pretty well. Most players say the game is unplayable for who have the newest OS, because there's a drop of FPS + laggy mouse and multiple crashes during the game, but there are some ways for fixing part of those problems if you read the threads in the community hub. So, think twice before buying it!
I use Windows XP and the game works fine except for some crashes (2 in 16 hours of gameplay, for me).

You should play it.
10/10

reviewText: WARNING! The game uses DirectDraw technology. That means that if you run anything newer then Windows XP you will encouter problems with this game. I have Windows 7 x64 and managed to bring the game to mostly playable level (the game slows for a second down everytime I change a character or choose a skill to use.\n\nThat said the game itself is quite excellent. The artstyle still looks just fine even though it is an old game. The 6 characters you will play as have variad skills, which you can use in creative way. There are no easy or scripted way through enemis and you will have to make your own way using tools given to you. The game is hard and you will have to use quicksave a lot on your first playthrough. Still, it is a great game in a long forgotten genre of games. It was fun back in 2001 and hold up really well to this day.

reviewText:
Short version: 89%Desperados is a squad-oriented stealth/action game following the footsteps of Commandos, but with a Western setting. It may be a copycat, but a copycat with great levels, good mechanics, and memorable characters, easily earning its rightful place among all real-time tactical game fans.

Long version:Desperados: Wanted Dead or Alive is the proof that you can create a copycat that can be on par with the original. In our case, it is a clone of Commandos: a series of WWII real-time squad-based tactical/strategy games, where you control a group of highly trained specialist through a set of mostly stealth-oriented levels.

The core mechanics are the same: your task is to clear each level from enemy guards and bandits to reach your current mission mark. To do so, you take control of a colourful cast of Western stereotypes, all with their unique abilities. They are maybe a little too unique, as even mundane tasks as tying a knot or saddling a horse need their own specialists.
Another similarity is that diversion tactics are the bread and butter of gameplay. This is where Desperados outdid Commandos: you can pre-record a set of commands for all characters to execute a complex plan with the push of a button. Thanks to the devilish enemy placements, this feature is almost essential after a while.
The setting makes one big difference though: we cannot have a Western without some shoot-outs, so Desperados puts a smaller emphasis on sneaking to give way for some old-fashioned gunplay instead.

The story is built from spaghetti Western tropes: a mysterious bandit leader pulls a few high-profile robberies, which attracts the attention of a veteran bounty hunter, who then collects a few outlaw buddies to get to the bottom of the events. After this, the plot runs into a few dead ends on purpose, which may be a little tiresome, but eventually it reaches its typical adventure-oriented Western movie conclusion.

reviewText:
So much pressure in my recent daily life and I found that video games couldn't offer me much relief as they did in the past.Talking about most games in my steam library,some of them I play for burdening purposes like achievement and most of them I play for reasons of nothing,I just have to play them because I bought them with stupid meaningless sense of ownership so I must play them to pay up the debt.And all of these,boring.

But This Game! I play this game for fun,for a long-lost feeling of self satisfaction and I just can't have enough of it,even though it has already offered a huge storyline of 25 delicately designed levels.I gave it my first try back in the days of 2001 and I just finished my 4th playing through yesterday,and I must say this game still doesn't seem to be out of date even after all these years,still has tons of new tactics to be tried out and still holds so many excellent funny little details to be discovered then grin my face.

What I like most is,this game has a large variaty of enemy types,and diffrences among them result in diffrent tactics(Just compare all these with those copy-paste nazi soldiers in Commandos series,you will see what revolution in enemy system Desperados Wanted Dead or Alive has brought in 2001.Even Commandos II Men of Courage wouldn't surpass it in this aspect )

All in all,this game offers me great enjoyment from which I've been away for so long.I own it my gratitude.

reviewText: A real gem from the Germany-based Spellbound from 2001! It plays exactly like the Commandos series except this time we find ourselves in the Wild West! You can control 6 characters throughout the 25 missions the game offers. Some are pretty hard (again, a similarity with Commandos) and quite long. The characters of course are not present in all missions - the game gives you a different variety all the time.\n\nThis was one of my favourite games more than 10 years ago! The game still looks decent as the levels are quite detailed and I'm sure there are a lot of people who can appreciate 2D graphics these days. If you liked Commandos and instead of replaying it you want something new feel free to pick this one up. It's only 1,24 EUR at the moment.
voteText: 17 of 20 people (85%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The first time I came across this game was somewhere around 2001. I got a copy of the demo on CD from a cereal box. I was instantly hooked on the game although it was very challenging. Sometime after that a friend of mine had received the full version of the game. We spent countless hours with the darn thing and we couldn't get past level four. But at that time, fooling around with the game was enough for me, so we started over many times and took turns playing. It wasn't about victory at all.

And now, more than ten years after the first glimpse, the game has landed on Steam, and I am eager to buy it. I got the game and I was instantly fulfilled with memories from the past. This is such a great game, there is no other like it. Commandos 2 and Robin Hood are close relatives, but there's something very special about this piece of art. The game features absolutely gorgeous graphics even with today's standards and the voice acting sounds more than professional.

If there's one thing they could have altered with the re-released version, it's the aspect ratio. There is no native widescreen support for the game, so you're stuck with 4:3 ratio. This however, isn't as big of a problem as one could think. Since it's an isometric game the gameplay doesn't look too bad at all even though it's stretched out. But just a fair warning...

reviewText:
Easily one of the best games ever made.

Amazing gameplay, different ways to complete levels. Are you into making noise with guns and killing a bunch of enemies at a time? Or you prefer sneaky one by one knife kill? Or maybe you want to poison your enemy, hide and watch as they kill one another? What about big boom with a dynamite? Your choice.

I completed this game at least 5 times already, and yet, every time I enjoy playing it and play each lvl differently, using different players and combinations. You can really finish a map in 10-15 minutes or 1 hr, all depends on your choice and actions. The farther you go into the game, the more fun maps are.

I will never delete this game from my pc. I know that each time, after completing the game, I will return and start all over again. Game control is simple and game price is just silly. You have nothing to lose.

reviewText: Striking graphics, realistic environments, interesting and diverse characters--what’s not to like? Really nothing.What makes it great is the fantastic level design and AI, the solid cut-scenes and storyline, the inventive character abilities and the fact that the designers have squeezed so much into it.I loved the fact that the characters know how to hide behind corners, pop out to shoot and then return to cover immediately, and the fact that you have to calm your hand for some time before you can fire a sniper-shot.

reviewText: Wild west themed, top down, isometric view, commandos style action game. In Desperados you control group of characters with their own strengths, abilities and uses. Game has rather enjoyable art style, with great, detailed environments. Characters have different abilities, weapons, items they can use to accomplish mission goals. Most of the time you have to use multiple characters to complete mission. There is a stealth element in this game, and in most missions you can complete it by silently knocking out, killing enemies, sneaking around undetected. Or you can raise hell and shoot everything that moves, but doing that you have low chances of survival. Game has some humor here and there, voice acting is decent. Game may not work on newer computers, running windows 7 and 8. Other than that it's fun game. If you enjoyed Commandos series, then you might like this.

reviewText:
I am running this on Windows 7 Pro 64bit. It works just as I remember back in 2001 when I first bought it! Many of you will have seen lots of comments and discussions about how this Steam version doesn't work well on newer versions of windows, including Windows 7 64bit. I read everything looking for the fixes, but it in the end Desperados worked perfectly without any patches or modifications. I'm guessing the developers cleaned up this release over the last 3-4 months so credit to them.

If you haven't played Desperados before, it is essentially Commandos 2 but set in the wild west with hilarious cliches to the max! Very fun, lots of character, beautiful artwork (although it has obviously aged quite a bit), excellent story, and lots of tactical variety. There are many ways of getting through each level, and the difficulty scales up nicely.

Bargain at a fiver.

reviewText:
Mission 13: I give up, this is just too frustrating. Horrible ♥♥♥♥ing game, almost nothing works as it should (and everything happens slooooooooooooooooowly), the game mechanics are downright broken. No wonder Spellbound went under.

There's only one thing I don't understand: the good reviews at the time. Has any reviewer even completed half of this game? The first few levels are charming but then the flaws start coming out more and more to the point where the whole thing becomes a barely playable mess.

Let's take the supposedly 3D environment that would let you take advantage of the height differences. The idea is great, hell, it's even more realistic than what you have in Commandos... but the developers just forgot to program it 75% of the time. You're crouched behind a small wall? Doesn't matter if it's not programmed to make you hidden, guards will just spot you even on a night mission.

To make things worse the game is just full of great ideas that simply doesn't work as they should. It was awesome to see that Sam can take control of gatling guns... then I got the chance to use one in mission 9 to find out that it's absolutely useless.

Dynamite? Have fun spending half a minute with getting it to the right position with the trajectory display before you throw it instead of you know, having it work in the obvious way (you click on a spot that's in range, you throw it there and it explodes but nope, that would have been too casual" I guess
date: too logical for a game like this).\n\nSleeping gas? Again the idea is great but the Doc can't throw it above a ♥♥♥♥ing wall. The first time I managed to make myself go to sleep instead of an enemy I laughed by the 5th time I was furious. The worst part of this is that it just makes reactive gameplay non-functional
recommended: you can't just lure a group of enemies to a corner and throw some sleeping gas at them because it's just too slow and the trajectory is too random (sometimes you can throw it well enough
hoursPlayed: sometimes you can't and the 2D graphics makes it hard to judge without waiting for the trajectory to be displayed - why isn't that instant btw?). Also it's sleeping gas you know: a guard shouldn't just kick a gassed collegue out of it
voteText: it's a chemical substance that makes you sleep.\n\nThe 2D graphics btw? They get in the way too much. You know why Commandos very rarely made you do things outside of your field of view? Because that's bad game design. I shouldn't do stuff blindly
helpfulPercent: ever.\n\nThe worst thing however? This game simply doesn't let you make even the smallest mistakes which is again horrendous game design. I should be able to make a mistake and correct it by reacting accordingly (you know
votesHelpful: like in Commandos) but here? Nope
votesFunny: get shot in the face and it's time to reaload.\n\nHorrendous
column19: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great game that I would recommend to anyone that like action and strategy games.

The game is around 20 hours long (Ignore my game time, I had to run the .exe directly to get things to work a bit more smooth) and it has a pretty good story although I would have liked to have a few bounty hunting missions at the start like the demo was, before getting set off on the adventure.

The game play is fun, not easy at all and you will spend a lot of time watching your enemies to learn their routine, then act on it using a range of abilities that each of the characters have. Strategy goes a long way as shooting your way out usually does not end well.

Like several people mentioned though, this game do not work to well with Windows 8, although I cannot confirm this as I have Windows 7 64x. With my play though, the issue I ran into the most was crashing, anywhere from 1 - 4 times a mission, but it wasn't enough to ruin the game as it loads fast and easy to continue from where you crashed (If you quicksave a lot).

reviewText: Desperados; Wanted Dead or Alive is an isometric point and click adventure game set in the wild west.  The story is entertaining and there are voice-overs.  The voice acting is atmospheric but comes across slightly stilted.  Graphics are dated by today's standards, but were really good for the time the game was made.  Overall the game is fun to play and good value for money if you pick it up on a Steam sale.

reviewText: EDIT: I'm not sure what happened but this problem has disappeared for me. The game seems to work perfectly now on Windows 7 x64, no cursor trailing in the menus or anything so far, so I'm changing my review to positive.\n\nI wanted to give this game a good review but unfortunately it has serious issues on modern operating systems. There are many fixes around but none of them remedy the problem 100%. The best fix I've seen is to use a customized DDraw.dll which causes an annoying graphics glitch in the menus where your mouse pointer leaves a trail. I don't think you should be selling a game that doesn't work properly.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: It took me a year to beat this game - I got pretty bored after about a dozen of missions, because every one of them requires almost the same actions to take and is about an hour long. However, the difficulty level causes great satisfaction after making your way through every group of enemies. So, if you plan to finish this game, you must arm yourself with patience. You could need even more of it, if you encounter the same issues as I did - during my gameplay (on W7x64), the game was FREEZING A LOT and the only way was to kill the process from the task manager.\n\nThis game can be fun over time, but can get dull if you play it too much.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games released in the early 2000s. It is one of the most rewarding strategy games I've played, with an engrossing movie-like atmosphere. The AI is quite advanced, with each (kind of) enemy reacting differently to the player's tactics, and can be quite punishing when playing stealthily.

Sadly, though, it hasn't aged well. While there are wide-screen patches available, this DirectX 7 game runs poorly on Windows 7 and later, so keep that in mind if you're considering buying it.

On the other hand it runs almost flawlessly on Linux under Wine, so it is a must buy for strategy/western Linux gamers!

reviewText:
Like many of my fellow gamers who own and play this game, most of us found this gem as a gift among our favourite cereal  and play that demo until the game was unreadable. Then we saved up to buy full game or if we were lucky it was bought for us and the magic of this game continued, i still have my hard copy of this game and demo and when i saw on steam i had to have it as it was and childhood reminder of good gaming. How it took forever at that bloody loading screen, but it was worth it!

Good gameplay
Good  2D graphics (for the time)
Great story and characters (made you feel part of the game)
Prefect strategy and stealth game

I hope that Nordic games can bring it back to life so it can run on newer OS's

reviewText:
First of all: yes, this game is nearly unplayable on Windows 7 and newer. I applied an official patch, but it didn't help a lot. At the beginning, the game froze every 5 minuts, so I had to kill it and start again. Then, after few levels, the situation was better. Frequency of freezing was lower and lower. Finaly, I was able to play few last levels without any problems.

I tolerated all of those restarting because:
- starting this game on curent computers with SSD disk is really fast
- you can (and you should) use quick-save all the time
- this old good stealth western game is just AWESOME

I enjoyed the game 15 years ago, and I enjoyed it again.
